Award.AwardTitle: NUE: NanO StUdio: An Immersive Ambience for Nano Educational Experiences

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Nanotechnology Undergraduate Education (NUE) in Engineering program entitled, "NUE: NanO StUdio: An Immersive Ambience for Nano Educational Experiences", at Ohio University under the direction of Dr. Savas Kaya, will establish an innovative and immersive educational platform, the nanO stUdio, for undergraduates at Ohio University. The nanO stUdio is a publicly accessible showroom run by a team of undergraduates and designed to impress audio-visually and provide hands-on educational experiences related to nanomaterials, nanostructures, nanosensors, nanodevices and advanced microscopy techniques. The nanO stUdio is the product of a vision to bring the nano-scale science and engineering out of the sterile clean room environments to the public level where both the students and visitors can explore new developments, and have a realistic and correct understanding of the materials, devices and capabilities endowed by nanotechnology.

The proposed learning studio concept goes well beyond the development of a conventional laboratory component or courseware, which has been the focus of many NUE proposals to date. In addition to the major objective of undergraduate student recruitment and training, the project also provides a means for the area high school students, parents and other interested parties to learn about principles and tools used in nanoscience and nanoengineering. As a crosscutting program, it will also provide summer research opportunities and stipends for the undergraduate students in the impoverished and underserved southeastern corner of Ohio bordering West Virginia and Kentucky.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NanOstUdio is a new interactive learning platform developed for the undergraduate engineering students at Ohio University (OU) that aims at increasing interest and involvement in nanotechnology via hands-on training and use of advanced microscopy tools. Additionally, it also serves as a new recruitment tool for nanotechnology educators and researchers at OU. The project is designed to impact regional efforts in STEM education in general, and nanotechnology in particular, by developing novel educational modules and concepts that can be emulated by others. Accordingly, the major outcomes of this project can be grouped as follows

-       A novel and innovative studio space has been setup in the new Academic and Research Center (ARC) annex, which houses all the new teaching/demo equipment as well as the audio/visual elements. Thus a new teaching, exploration, research space has been dedicated to undergraduates on campus.

-       On the educational front, nanOstUdio has become an indispensible tool for nanotechnology education and demonstration in the college of engineering and beyond. It is the only platform dedicated to the undergraduate education, is open to class and school visits.

-       24 undergraduate and 5 graduate assistants have been trained as active demonstrators/explorers, who regularly interacted with hundreds of campus students and visitors. A large portion of this undergraduate cohort also served as summer interns and research assistants on a wide range of projects ranging from atomic resolution STM images to printed sensors and nanomaterials.

-       NanOstUdio, made up from compact, portable and easy to use electron scanning microscope, atomic force microscope and scanning electron microscope, is essentially a lab ‘on wheels’. All the tools have been setup on mobile mini desks and can be easily transported to other locations. It has been used to many site visits and demonstrations on and off campus sites.

-       Studio has become also a STEM recruitment and outreach vehicle for the college, as it has been regularly used to make demonstrations to prospective students, parents and visitors. This is very exciting and important as the college is enjoying record enrollment numbers, thanks in part to such interactive and student-run demonstrations.

-       Several virtual instruments and molecular visualization tools have been developed that have been setup with interactive (hand-off) interface devices on audiovisual systems to allow younger visitors and general public to be informed on nanomaterials. See the smartphone application at Android PlayStore (Nano-Studio) and associated website http://nano-studio.github.io
